title: WDS Limited enters a trading halt
text:
A contractor to some of Australia's biggest energy and mining companies was in financial distress on Wednesday evening, after a larger than expected full year loss breached debt covenants.
WDS Limited, which has recently worked on all three of the Gladstone LNG projects as well as on coal mines for South32, Glencore, Yancoal, Peabody and Vale, went into a trading halt on Wednesday pending an announcement about a "contractual issue" with a customer.
It is unclear who that customer is, but it is known that WDS was involved in an "ignition" event at Vale's Eagle Downs coal mine earlier this year, and that interruption was a major factor in WDS' loss for the 2015 financial year blowing out to an expected $28 million.
That loss is double what was expected, and is believed to breach covenants on the debt that WDS has with GE.
Advertisement WDS conceded it had raised its debt issues with a lender earlier this month.
"The company will breach the financial ratios contained in the loan facility agreement, in particular the fixed charge cover ratio. We are in discussions with our lender in relation to this matter," the company said on August 11.
Neither GE nor WDS returned calls on Wednesday evening, and WDS is expected to update the market on Thursday.
Contractors to the mining and energy sectors have been among the worst hit by the commodities slump, with several companies, such as Forge Group collapsing under the strain.
WDS is believed to be in the middle of a labour supply contract at South32's Appin mine in the Illawarra, as well as Shell's Daandine coal seam gas project in Queensland.
